-JyiwKGGYqOWt9CA_ZTs.explanation: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. [My father owns the stamp collection] Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. [The sails belong to the ship] Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word. Whatever comes after the possessive noun belongs to it. For example, my father's stamp collection and the ship's sail are possessive nouns.

If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rL.explanation:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.

-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rM.explanation:

-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rN.explanation:

If a female subject (Jasmine) does something to herself, we use a reflexive pronoun (herself). In the second example, the subject (He) is listening to someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.

-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rO.explanation:
Reflexive: My computer can shut itself off. Non-Reflexive: I can shut down my computer.
If an object (computer) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (itself). In the second example, the subject of the sentence (I) is shutting the computer down, and not shutting himself down, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rO.title: Itself

-JyiwKGIWX4axaHpe0rP.explanation:

Vague: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. She works really hard. Specific: Mary orchestrated tonight's show, while Tia was in charge of all the design work. Tia works really hard.
In the first example, it is not clear whether she refers to Mary or to Tia.
In the second sentence Tia replaces she, making it clear who works really hard.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_J.title: Vague Pronouns: More Than One Subject

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_L.explanation:
Correct: My sister, who just received her law degree, is moving to New York. Incorrect: My sister who just received her law degree is moving to New York.
We put commas before and after nonrestrictive clauses (,who just received her law degree,). Nonrestrictive clauses provide additional information about a subject. We use these commas to show that this information is less important.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_L.title: Commas Around Clauses

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_N.explanation:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_N.title: Using Periods

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_O.explanation:
Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_O.title: Using Commas

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_P.explanation:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_P.title: Using Commas with Numbers

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_Q.explanation:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_Q.title: Using Periods with Numbers

-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_R.explanation: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).
-JyiwKGKb3AGIpNPvk_R.title: Comparative Adjectives

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcaz.explanation: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcaz.title: Adjectives Ending in ""y""

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb-.explanation: Correct: James is the tallest guy in school. Incorrect: James is the most tall guy in school. Superlative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is the ""most"" or ""least"". Regular superlative adjectives are formed by adding ""est"" to the end of a word (**tallest**).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb-.title: Superlative Adjectives

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb0.explanation: Correct: Are papayas the healthiest fruit of all? Incorrect: Are papayas the healthyest fruitof all? To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) superlative, we change the ""y"" to an ""iest"" to the end of the word (**healthiest**).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb0.title: Adjectives ending in ""y"" (Superlative)

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb1.explanation: Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for ""good"" is better. The superlative adjective for ""good"" is best.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb1.title: Better & Best

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb2.explanation: Correct: It is worse to have never tried than to fail. Incorrect: It is badder to have never tried than to fail. The comparative adjective for ""bad"" is worse. The superlative adjective for ""bad"" is worst.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb2.title: Worse & Worst

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb3.explanation: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb3.title: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb7.explanation: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.

concept_level_1.name: Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb9.explanation: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).

answers.text: '{""What a silly pup,""} Uncle Gary chuckled with a smile.'
'{""What a silly pup,""} uncle Gary chuckled with a smile.'

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb8.instructions: Rewrite the sentence, placing quotation marks around whatever is being said.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb8.prompt: What a silly pup, Uncle Gary chuckled with a smile.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb9.title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbA.explanation:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbA.title: Singular Possessive

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbB.explanation: Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbB.title: Plural Possessive

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbC.explanation: Exactly Two Options: You can have either soup or salad. Two Options, Maybe More: You can have soup or salad. Whenever either is placed before or, we are presented with exactly two options (soup or salad). If the two options share a verb, either is written after the verb (have either). If the two options have different verbs, either is written before the first verb (either have).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbC.title: Either ... Or

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbD.explanation: Not only … but also: He was not only an excellent athlete, but also a great musician. And: He was an excellent athlete and a great musician. We use not only and but also to connect two different ideas to something. We always place a comma before but also in these kinds of sentences. Not only is usually placed before one idea, while but also is used instead of the word ""and.""
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbD.title: Not Only ... But Also

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbE.explanation: Niether … nor: My friend is neither snowboarding nor skiing today. Either … or: My friend is either snowboarding or skiing today. Neither and nor are used the same way as the words ""either"" and ""or"". However, neither and nor are used for negative sentences.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbE.title: Neither ... Nor

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbF.explanation: With Both: Both Tom and Michelle like swimming. Without Both: Tom likes swimming. Michelle also likes swimming. Both can be used with and to describe two things at the same time (Both Tom and Michelle). We place both before the first thing, then use and for the second thing.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbF.title: Both ... And

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbG.explanation: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbG.title: Commas in a List

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbH.explanation: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbH.title: Colons

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbJ.explanation: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).

answers.text: We go apple picking in the fall. {However,} this year it was too cold.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbI.instructions: Rewrite the sentences, placing however at the beginning of the second sentence. (Don't forget to place a comma after however.)
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbI.prompt: We go apple picking in the fall. This year it was too cold.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbJ.title: However

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbK.explanation: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbK.title: Still

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbL.explanation: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbL.title: Meanwhile

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbM.explanation: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbM.title: Tag Questions

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbN.explanation: Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbN.title: Yes & No

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbO.explanation: Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbO.title: Addressing People

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbP.explanation: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbP.title: Regular Past Participles

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbQ.explanation: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbQ.title: Eaten

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbR.explanation: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbR.title: Been

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbT.explanation: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.

answers.text: I {lost} many games before becoming this skilled.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbT.title: Lost

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbU.explanation: Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbU.title: Made

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbV.explanation: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbV.title: Gone

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbW.explanation: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbW.title: Misplaced Modifiers

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb_.explanation: With ""and"": I just had a big and tasty calzone. Without ""and"": I just had a big, tasty calzone. Whenever you have two adjectives (big and tasty) describing something (calzone), you do not have to use ""and"" like you normally do for lists. You can write a comma after the first adjective to describe something (big, tasty calzone).

answers.text: The {big, red} ball bounced very high.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcb_.title: Two Adjectives

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcba.explanation: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcba.title: Using Quotation Marks

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbb.explanation: Active: I ate the chocolate bar on the table. Passive: The chocolate bar on the table was eaten. Verbs in the passive voice are made the same way past participles are made (eaten). They follow helping verbs like “was” and “were.”
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbb.title: The Passive Voice

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbd.explanation: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That had didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.

answers.text: She is a talented athlete, but she {has} poor sportsmanship.

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbe.explanation: Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"".
-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbe.title: Verb Mood Shift

-JyiwKGLDXm1prZkCcbf.explanation: With Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for..."" Without Ellipsis: ""I forgot what I went shopping for."" Ellipses are used in informal writing. Like commas, they are used to show a pause. However, the ellipsis is often used when someone is speaking, and can also be used to show that the person hasn't finished what he or she might have said.

That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.

Intensive: I myself organized the meeting. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the word emphasizes the the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). When the word is used as a reflexive pronoun, it emphasizes what the subject does to itself (organized myself).
